title: 111_hr3315
content: The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" requires national criminal background checks for child care providers licensed by the State or receiving funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" mandates comprehensive criminal background checks for eligible child care providers licensed by the State or receiving funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" requires background checks for job applicants and family child care providers seeking to provide services. Individuals with certain recent criminal convictions may be refused employment. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" mandates background checks for individuals applying for jobs or providing family child care services. Certain criminal convictions, including crimes of violence or crimes against children with penalties exceeding one year of imprisonment, may result in employment denial. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" requires background checks for individuals working with children. Eligible children must be supervised by employees with satisfactory criminal background checks. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" mandates comprehensive criminal background checks for employees and applicants of licensed child care providers funded by the State. The "Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009" requires States to conduct background checks on employees and applicants of licensed child care providers. The Secretary may waive this requirement for a State for one fiscal year if the State shows efforts to comply but inability to do so. If a State fails to comply substantially, the Secretary will reduce funding by 10 percent. The Secretary will reduce the State allotment by 10 percent for the following fiscal year in case of noncompliance. The Act and its amendments will take effect two years after enactment.
